thread.title: Leah Purcell wins the Victorian Prize for Literature
thread.title_full: Leah Purcell wins the Victorian Prize for Literature

title: Leah Purcell wins the Victorian Prize for Literature
text:
Image: Writer, director and actor Leah Purcell has won the Victorian Prize for Literature (Photo: Brett Boardman) 
Last night, Sydney-based Indigenous writer, director and actor Leah Purcell won the Victorian Prize for Literature for her play The Drover’s Wife . 
As well as winning the $100,000 Victorian Prize for Literature, Australia’s richest single literary prize, Purcell was named as the winner of the Prize for Drama, for which she won a further $25,000. 
The Drover’s Wife is a dramatic reimagining of Henry Lawson’s celebrated short story. 
In the words of the judging panel, the play ‘explodes out of the blocks with a moment of stark brutality and never lets up’. 
The Victorian Premier’s Literary Awards are administered by the Wheeler Centre on behalf of the Premier of Victoria. 
Below is a list of all the winners: 
VICTORIAN PRIZE FOR LITERATURE 
The Drover’s Wife by Leah Purcell (Currency Press) 
PRIZE FOR FICTION Between a Wolf and a Dog by Georgia Blain (Scribe Publications) 
PRIZE FOR NON-FICTION Offshore: Behind the wire on Manus and Nauru by Madeline Gleeson (NewSouth Publishing) 
PRIZE FOR DRAMA The Drover’s Wife by Leah Purcell (Currency Press) 
PRIZE FOR POETRY Carrying the World by Maxine Beneba Clarke (Hachette Australia) 
PRIZE FOR WRITING FOR YOUNG ADULTS When Michael Met Mina by Randa Abdel-Fattah (Pan Macmillan Australia) 
PEOPLE’S CHOICE
